III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth presented to the hospital with suicidal ideations and has a
plan for suicide. A safety plan was made and sent back to the
facility, but the facility is not able to provide 1:1 care.
Investigation Interviews:
Social Worker 1 was interviewed via telephone on October 30,
2024. Social Worker 1 said she was the tele-med hospital social
worker the overnight of October 21, 2024, into October 22, 2024.
Social Worker 1 said when she took over the case with Youth A
there were no facility staff present at the hospital with her. Social
Worker 1 said she was not involved in conversations or decisions
about not needing facility staff present at the hospital. Social
Worker 1 said she was told the facility was unable to provide
adequate staffing to ensure Youth A’s safety plan was met
therefore she was to be in the emergency room overnight. Social
Worker 1 said it was reported the facility would not have enough
staff for “a few days” but she was unsure what the staffing issues
were. Social Worker 1 said she was reaching out to the MDHHS
Worker as they were noted as the guardian for Youth A to notify
them of the current situation. Social Worker 1 said she was not
able to get in touch with the MDHHS Worker and therefore called
centralized intake.
Social Worker 2 was interviewed via telephone on November
4, 2024. Social Worker 2 said she was the tele-med hospital social
worker the evening of October 21, 2024, and worked with Youth A
on screening and safety planning. Social Worker 2 said throughout
her contact with Youth A, Medical Technician was present,
participated in the safety planning, and was providing her with
information regarding the safety plan and facilities resources.
Social Worker 2 said Medical Technician reported the facility
would not have the staffing available to ensure the safety plan was
2

met. Social Worker 2 said the Medical Technician was in contact
with her supervisor and reported that “within a day or two” they
would be able to have staff provide constant supervision which
would include having a staff within arm’s reach of Youth A at all
times while awake, and while asleep have a staff sit outside Youth
A’s door and complete five minute checks on her throughout the
night. Social Worker 2 said due to this information it was
determined Youth A would spend the night in the hospital so that
the facility had time to increase staffing to meet the safety plan
requirements. Social Worker 2 said she never took part in a
conversation regarding the hospital providing Youth A’s
supervision and facility staff not being needed at the hospital, but
Medical Technician had stated she planned to stay with Youth A as
long as needed.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
November 18, 2024. Youth A said she was at the hospital “a few
weeks ago” and Medical Technician was with her for part of the
time. Youth A said Medical Technician left due to not “being able to
count in ratio”. Youth A said she was left alone at the hospital for
“a couple of hours”. Youth A said once she returned to River Oak
she was on “constant supervision” and had a staff with her at all
times when she was awake and sat in her doorway at night.
Medical Technician was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on October 23, 2024. Medical Technician said she took Youth A to
the hospital for an assessment due to her suicidal statements.
Medical Technician said she was in the room and Social Worker 2
was on a tablet, and Supervisor was on the phone when they did
the safety planning for Youth A. Medical Technician said Social
Worker 2 wanted Youth A to have one-on-one staffing and
Supervisor said they cannot provide one-on-one staffing due to
ratio and staffing however they would provide constant supervision
of Youth A. Medical Technician said Social Worker 2 asked how
long the constant supervision would last and Supervisor had said
he cannot give a specific timeframe as it is based on the youth’s
needs and behaviors. Medical Technician said Social Worker 2
said Youth A was to stay at the hospital and they were going to get
in touch with Youth A’s Foster Care Worker. Medical Technician
said once it was determined that Youth A was to stay overnight at
the emergency room, she was directed by Health Administrator to
leave the hospital as they were going to place a staff in Youth A’s
room. Medical Technician said she told Director and left the
hospital. Medical Technician said the following day she and Health
Administrator went back to the emergency room and picked Youth
3

A up and brought her back to the facility. Medical Technician said
she did not see the safety plan once back at the facility.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
October 23, 2024. Supervisor said Medical Technician was at the
hospital with Youth A on October 21, 2024. Supervisor said
Medical Technician called him as she was working with Social
Worker 2 on the safety plan for Youth A. Supervisor said Social
Worker 2 was asking the facility to staff one-on-one for Youth A
and he reported he told Medical Technician to tell the Social
Worker 2 they could not provide one-on-one staff with Youth A
however they would be able to provide constant supervision to her
which would include staff having her in line-of-sight, and
conducting five-minute checks on her at night. Supervisor said it is
his understanding Social Worker 2 made the ultimate decision to
keep her at the hospital overnight and then she returned the
following morning and is on constant supervision.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
October 23, 2024. Director said Therapist assessed Youth A for
suicidal statements and made the decision to have staff bring her
to the hospital for further assessment. Director said the safety plan
for Youth A was developed by her, Therapist, and Supervisor.
Director said the safety plan is placed in the staff binder for them
to review, and then discussed further in the weekly staff meeting.
Director said Medical Technician was at the hospital with Youth A
and at some point Health Administrator directed Medical
Technician to leave Youth A at the hospital with no staff. Director
said Medical Technician reached out to her to tell her and she then
reached out to Health Administrator who told them they had to go
back to the hospital and was told by Health Administrator that the
hospital agreed to provide the supervision to Youth A and staff was
not needed.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
November 6, 2024. Foster Care Worker said she received a
voicemail regarding Youth A’s hospitalization on October 21, 2024.
Foster Care Worker said she spoke to someone from the hospital
who told her that River Oak staff reported that in order to have
Youth A returned to the facility they needed one-on-one staffing.
Foster Care Worker said she then spoke to the staff at River Oak
who reported they never told the hospital they needed one-on-one
staffing but rather the hospital said that was required for discharge
of Youth A. Foster Care Worker said the River Oak staff said they
would place Youth A on constant supervision and develop a safety
plan with frequent checks on Youth A. Foster Care Worker said
4

she has not had any concerns with River Oak program and
reported they go above and beyond with Youth A.
Health Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
November 25, 2024. Health Administrator reported most of her
prior work has been in a hospital and she is familiar with hospital
protocols regarding youth that come in with mental health needs
and the supervision the hospital provides for them. Health
Administrator said she was on the phone with Medical Technician
on October 21, 2024, while Youth A was in the emergency room.
Health Administrator said there was miscommunication in the
terminology that was being used for Youth A’s safety plan which
made the hospital social worker decide to have Youth A remain in
the emergency room overnight. Health Administrator said she was
not included in the discussion about the terminology so is unsure
of what the issue had been exactly. Health Administrator said once
it was decided Youth A was going to stay in the emergency room
for the night, she spoke to the charge nurse who told her there
would be a “sitter” in Youth A’s room to ensure safety and doing
ten minutes charting. Health Administrator said she then spoke to
Director of Quality and explained to her that the hospital was
going to provide a “sitter” and so felt the Medical Technician
should leave and it was not necessary to have another staff go to
the hospital to sit with Youth A as she would already have a
hospital staff in the room the entire time. Health Administrator said
Director of Quality agreed so she told Medical Technician to leave
the hospital. Health Administrator said the following morning she
and Medical Technician went to emergency room to get Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• River Oak Youth Center Suicide Prevention Plan Policy was
reviewed. Constant Supervision is defined as “the
continuous and uninterrupted observation of a youth by a
staff member assigned to monitor the youth who has a
clear and unobstructed view of the youth, and unobstructed
sound monitoring of the youth at all times.”
• Youth A’s after visit summary from Corewell Health dated
October 21, 2024. Youth A had been in the emergency
room for “suicidal ideation” and was diagnosed with
“emotional crisis and suicidal ideation”. The summary
included a safety plan for Youth A, addressing warning
signs, coping skills, people whom Youth A could talk to,
professional agencies to contact during a crisis, and steps
to make the environment safe for her. In additional to these
steps the hospital recommended “facility implement safety
protocol: 1:1 monitoring, 5-minute bed checks, continued
5

medication management, pt to return to River Oaks,
recommend attempting to move up Psychiatry
appointment.”
• River Oak Safety Plan for Youth A dated October 22, 2024,
was reviewed. The safety plan is as follows:
o [Youth A] is on Constant supervision
o 30 mins checks during the day
o 5 min checks at night
o If [Youth A] steps outside the house without staff
supervision, she is imminent risk to harm and is
required to be physically managed.
o No pencils or erasers
• River Oak Safety Plan for Youth A dated November 3,
2024, was reviewed. The safety plan is as follows:
o [Youth A] will reduce the frequency of her AWOL or
leaving the program.
o [Youth A] will utilize boundaries of the yard – mailbox
to the pine tree.
o [Youth A] is working towards communication with
staff regarding her feelings.
o [Youth A] will work to earn incentives on a monthly
basis and will review her goals every 30 days.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews the facility
was willing to provide constant supervision for Youth A per the
requested safety plan.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was provided the facility update the safety
plan as physical management cannot be prescribed as physical
management needs to be assessed during each incident to
determine if it is warranted based on the licensing rules.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
